repnme.cdata!:
Africa Region - Regional HIV/AIDS Treatment
            Acceleration Program Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Regional HIV/AIDS
            Treatment Acceleration Program Project for Africa Region
            were as follows: outcomes were moderately satisfactory, the
            risk to development outcome was high, the Bank performance
            was moderately unsatisfactory, and the Borrower performance
            was also moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: sub-regional HIV/AIDS projects require a project
            design that clearly defines the roles and responsibilities
            of the multiple participating national and regional
            institutions. Multiple stakeholders generate diverse views,
            approaches and understandings that need to be addressed
            during project preparation or immediately after the project
            becomes effective. Government ownership and leadership is a
            core requirement for successful institutional arrangements
            and therefore establishing the institutional framework for
            program implementation is an essential step during the
            preparation phase. Regional projects take more time to reach
            agreements on institutional arrangements, including funds
            allocation. Public-private approaches and partnerships with
            non-state actors have shown to be useful to quickly scale-up
            anti-retroviral treatment programs. Long term partnerships
            however are only viable with assurances of continued
            financing whether domestic or external. Sharing information
            is important to the success of regional programs as it
            fosters regional learning. The regional advisory
            (RAP's) panels proved to be an important mechanism for
            those purposes and could be relevant for other programs in
            health in Africa and beyond. RAPs facilitated learning and
            served a useful forum for exchanging knowledge and
            experience and especially fostering a south-south exchange.
            Fiduciary processes and reporting for United Nation (UN)
            agencies need to be clarified during project preparation.

repnme.cdata!:
Africa Region - Regional HIV/AIDS Treatment
            Acceleration Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Regional HIV/AIDS
            Treatment Acceleration Project (TAP) is to contribute to the
            learning and knowledge base as a means of optimizing service
            delivery of HIV/AIDS program particularly in regards to the
            benefits, risks, risk mitigation and management modalities
            of anti-retroviral treatment scale-up. There are three
            components to the project. The first component of the
            project is testing approaches for scaling-up service
            delivery for HIV/AIDS care and treatment. These service
            delivery approaches would be tested through implementing
            partners identified at country level, who have demonstrated
            success at providing HIV/AIDS care and treatment on a small
            scale. Specifically, the implementing partners include
            associations of people living with HIV/AIDS in Burkina Faso,
            international Non-government organizations (NGOs) in
            Mozambique, and private sector clinics and organizations in
            Ghana. The second component of the project is strengthening
            institutional capacity for HIV/AIDS care and treatment to
            ensure adequate referral mechanisms to support the
            activities of the implementing partners and build overall
            capacity within the Ministry of Health to scale up national
            HIV/AIDS treatment coverage. The third and the final
            component of the project is facilitating regional learning
            from the TAP countries, with World Health Organization (WHO)
            providing technical capacity support for the Ministries of
            Health and implementing partners, while United Nations
            Economic Commission for Africa (UNECA) would support
            cross-border learning and dissemination of lessons learned
            within the African continent.
